qas.question: Who ruled most of India in the 18 century?

qas.question: What caused the death of Emperor Auranzeb?
Where was the Maratha Empire centralized?
What caused the Maratha Empire to split in 1761?

answers.text: the Maratha army lost the Third Battle of Panipat

context: On the Indian subcontinent, the <a0_0><a5_0>Mughal Empire<a5_0/><a0_0/> ruled most of India in the early 18th century. The "classic period" ended with <a1_0><a6_0>the death and defeat of Emperor Aurangzeb<a6_0/> in 1707<a1_0/> by <a7_0>the rising <a2_0>Hindu Maratha Empire<a2_0/>,<a7_0/> although the dynasty continued for another 150 years. During this period, the Empire was marked by a highly centralized administration connecting the different regions. All the significant monuments of the Mughals, their most visible legacy, date to this period which was characterised by the expansion of Persian cultural influence in the Indian subcontinent, with brilliant literary, artistic, and architectural results. The Maratha Empire was located in the <a3_0><a8_0>south west of present-day India<a8_0/><a3_0/> and expanded greatly under the rule of the Peshwas, the prime ministers of the Maratha empire. In 1761, <a9_0>the Maratha army lost the Third Battle of Panipat<a9_0/> which halted imperial expansion and <a4_0>the empire was then divided into a confederacy of Maratha states.
